As someone who works with 3d printers on a daily basis, my experience is that they are not quite as magical as people make them out to be.  Granted, I am mostly using cheep, home-built printers, not high-end, cell-printing ones.  However, when people are saying things like print computers, guns etc, that just doesn't seem viable to me.  A given extruder nozzle can only print one type of material at a time, and if you get too surfaces too close to each other (about 1 mm), they tend to melt together. At best, you could print each part to something separately and assemble them by hand.  Also, there are significant limitations in terms of the shapes you can print, since everything is done in layers and has to be able to support itself with only small overhangs.

I'm currently wearing/hooked up to what's called a wound vac. I broke my back 4 months ago and devloped an infection in the incision area on my wounded back, from the first surgery. My 2nd surgery was "exploratory," basically cutting me open again to clean out the ecolei infection. Long story short, I have a big wound on my lower back, initially being 6.5 cm. deep, now 3.4 cm. deep after three months. It's hermetically sealed with sponge like material, hooked up to a tube running into the "vac" which sucks out blood, remaining infected tissue, etc. The healing process takes about six months for my wound to completely heal, and that's sped up due to the "vac."

This is a rather simple question to answer, No. They won't because the items they produce will only be good for very light use, there is a reason why they have only been used for prototyping basic things for companies for 20 years now.
The way the layers are put down don't make for an effective bond, it might work great for living tissues where they will naturally bond together but things like plastics and metals.. Nope.
For the people stupidly saying "They have made 3D printed guns already!" No... No they haven't they had made GRIPS and HANDLES but the actual mechanical parts would be far too weak to fire a bullet and would likely kill the handler then the person it was pointed at.

Now comment on the effectiveness of 3D printing, which in the case of mechanical parts seems likely to result in products that are going to be more breakable in one direction than they are in another direction.  Compare with, say, machining, which can just as readily be computer-controlled and individualized.

What something is made of, and how it is made, have significant impacts on the lifespan and fitness-for-use of an object.

For anyone curious on how to get into 3D printing as a hobby, I would recommend researching Reprap 3D printers.  They can be put together for under $500 and are very capable machines.  They can print plastic items out of ABS (Legos) or PLA (made from a starch).  The schematics are open source, and even about 50% of the printer is made of printed parts (Mendel Prusa variation).  The one I built a couple years ago still works flawlessly today.

So I intend to have a 3D printer in my home early next year. I really doubt the world is going to change that much in that time as the video states. Thousands of people have personal 3D printers now. You can buy a fairly decent one with no technical knowledge necessary for under $600. Further adoption will lower the price to under $200. For the price of a car you can buy one that prints plastic in millions of colors that is hard enough to use as a wrench.

The true change is going to come when we can buy a 3D printer that will create whatever food we need. This is especially true if we can make that printer economical enough for those living where food is scarce. Maybe that won't be possible.

One scenario we I have discussed with someone is replacing meat with a perfect printed substitute. Most likely this will be possible some day, even if not practical. He pointed out the irony that if it became practical and publicly embraced as a cure for animal cruelty in the food chain, vegetarians would be in for a big surprise as they witnessed one of the greatest slaughters in history as farmers ditched their no longer profitable livestock.

Behold everyone, The Replicator from "Star Trek" is soon upon us! Why buy a PS4, when you can make one!? :) (on that note I can see the ability to buy a product replicating Licence replacing the purchase of the item if it comes to pass.)

I envision huge advancements in electronics within the next decade. For example, right now your phone is a collection of chips and other components all made by different manufacturers. Processor by ARM, memory by AMD, flash by Fujitsu, CDMA chip by Motorola, battery by Sony, and so on. All these chips need to be connected together using a PCB. This is horribly inefficient. It is technically possible to combine all of the functionality of the entire phone into a single component - but it'd be far too expensive right now. A chip design requires a ton of work, plus there's the expense of the manufacturing line and the machines custom built to produce just that chip. Once you can print entire chips using additive manufacturing, however, this all changes. Your phone can be 1/4 the size it is now, as almost the entire phone would be one big single component with no PCB required to glue it all together. Want to add more RAM? Add new wireless capability? More flash or less flash? An engineer can do this by editing the design and the same 3d printer can produce the new version of the phone.

But what happens when we can replicate atoms as easily as we can replicate bits?

What if someone can just pirate Lego bricks? Does Lego own that design? Even if they do, can they possibly pursue legal action against everyone who will inevitably copy it? We know that's not the case with music.

3D printing sounds like an amazing idea until you realize the harm it can cause as well. We've already seen people 3D printing guns, and though they're not yet practical in functionality, it requires very little imagination to see a future where they will be as good as anything you can buy now.

But that's no reason to fear the 3D printing revolution as guns harm relatively few people compared to something like, say, a pandemic. Using 3D printers to whip up some pharmaceuticals is great, but the same process could also be used to whip up designer viruses someday.

By no means am I suggesting we should halt the advancement of this technology, and even if I was it would be ridiculous as you cannot halt advancement. I'm just pointing out a few glaring problems that we'll have to eventually face.

Fact: Traditional manufacturing won´t go away, 3D printing only helps to quickly make models and prototypes for small iteration, but I see little use of it in mass production. Why? Because it is cheaper to mill/bend/weld/whatever a piece out of raw material rather than use tons of expensive fluids to slowly progress a piece out of thin air and bake it into solid shape.
